<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of do_append:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
do_append (char **ret,
           const char *data,
           size_t size)
{
  char *buf;
  size_t old_len;

  if (NULL == *ret)
    old_len = 0;
  else
    old_len = strlen (*ret);
  if (NULL == (buf = malloc (old_len + size + 1)))
    return MHD_NO;
  if (NULL != *ret)
  {
    memcpy (buf,
            *ret,
            old_len);
    free (*ret);
  }
  memcpy (&buf[old_len],
          data,
          size);
  buf[old_len + size] = '\0';
  *ret = buf;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. Rule 14.3 concerns invariant controlling expressions (e.g., loops or conditionals whose control expression is a compile-time constant or otherwise always the same). The provided function contains no loops and only three if statements: (1) if (NULL == *ret) — depends on the runtime value of *ret; (2) if (NULL == (buf = malloc (old_len + size + 1))) — depends on the runtime result of malloc; (3) if (NULL != *ret) — depends on the runtime value of *ret. None of these are invariant controlling expressions. There is no do-while with an integer constant expression, and no infinite-loop constructs using constant true. Therefore no code fragments require investigation for Rule 14.3.
